Energy-Efficient Channel Decoding for Wireless Federated Learning: Convergence Analysis and Adaptive Design

Linping Qu,Â  Yuyi Mao,Â 
Shenghui Song,Â  and Chi-Ying Tsui This work was partially supported by AI Chip Center for Emerging Smart System (ACCESS) sponsored by InnoHK funding, Hong Kong, SAR, and partially supported by a grant from the NSFC/RGC Joint Research Scheme sponsored by the Research Grants Council of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region, China and National Natural Science Foundation of China (Project No. N_HKUST656/22). Linping Qu, Shenghui Song, and Chi-Ying Tsui are with the Department of Electronic and Computer Engineering, Hong Kong University of Science and Technology, Hong Kong (e-mail: lqu@connect.ust.hk; eeshsong@ust.hk; eetsui@ust.hk). Yuyi Mao is with the Department of Electrical and Electronic Engineering, Hong Kong Polytechnic University, Hong Kong (e-mail: yuyi-eie.mao@polyu.edu.hk).
Abstract

One of the most critical challenges for deploying distributed learning solutions, such as federated learning (FL), in wireless networks is the limited battery capacity of mobile clients. While it is a common belief that the major energy consumption of mobile clients comes from the uplink data transmission, this paper presents a novel finding, namely the channel decoding operation also contributes significantly to the overall energy consumption of mobile clients in FL. Motivated by this new observation, we propose an energy-efficient adaptive channel decoding scheme that leverages the intrinsic robustness of FL to model errors. In particular, the robustness is exploited to reduce the energy consumption of channel decoders at mobile clients by adaptively adjusting the number of decoding iterations. We theoretically prove that wireless FL with communication errors can converge at the same rate as the case with error-free communication as long as the bit error rate (BER) is properly constrained. An adaptive channel decoding scheme is then proposed to improve the energy efficiency of wireless FL systems. Experimental results demonstrate that the proposed method maintains the same learning accuracy while reducing the channel decoding energy consumption by 20% when compared to existing approaches.

Index Terms:
Federated learning (FL), energy efficiency, channel decoding, low-density parity checking (LDPC), bit error rate (BER).

I Introduction

I-A Motivation

Deep learning has achieved remarkable success in numerous realms, such as computer vision and natural language processing [1]. However, the conventional centralized learning paradigm encounters the data isolation issue due to the rising concern about privacy [2]. As a result, uploading the distributed data, which may contain privacy-sensitive information, for centralized learning becomes prohibited. To address this issue, federated learning (FL) was proposed [3] to enable the distributed training of deep learning models without sharing the data of users (e.g., IoT devices). However, to fully unlock the potential of FL, we need to tackle several critical challenges, such as data and device heterogeneity [4, 5, 6], as well as the communication bottleneck[7]. Another issue of wireless FL is the energy consumption of mobile clients due to heavy computation and communication workloads for training and transferring the deep neural network (DNN) parameters[8].

Many innovative approaches have been proposed to reduce the energy consumption of mobile clients in FL from different perspectives. For instance, reinforcement learning was utilized in [9] to identify near-optimal client selection and resource allocation to reduce both the convergence time and energy consumption of mobile clients. In [10], the trade-off between learning accuracy and total energy consumption of users was optimized through computational and communication resource allocation. In [11], the transmission and computation energy was minimized by bandwidth allocation and power control. Besides system-level resource management, techniques such as model sparsification [12] and quantization [13, 14, 15, 16, 17, 18] have been proposed to minimize the communication overhead, thus reducing the energy consumption of the transmitters. Authors of [19] minimized the transmission energy consumption of mobile clients while maintaining the learning performance by optimizing the transmit power, user selection and uplink resource allocation. Authors of [20] adopted quantization and periodic aggregation to reduce the transmission volume and energy, which also provided a theoretical framework about the impact of quantization and periodic aggregation on the convergence rate of FL. Model sparsification and quantization techniques are also beneficial for minimizing the processing energy consumption [21, 8]. Authors of [21] proposed to introduce sparsity at training time to reduce the on-device training energy. Authors of [8] reduced the local computation energy by quantization on both DNN weights and activations.

However, most works on energy-efficient FL focused on the energy consumption of mobile transmitters while few of them paid attention to the energy consumption of channel decoders in mobile receivers. As will be shown in Section II-B, channel decoders consume a substantial proportion of energy because of the iterative processes to decode massive DNN parameters in each communication round of wireless FL.

To address the research gap, in this work, we first quantitatively analyze the energy consumption of different components in a mobile unit and show that the channel decoder contributes significantly to the overall energy consumption. Building on this observation, an energy-efficient adaptive channel decoding scheme is proposed for wireless FL systems, by leveraging the fact that FL is robust to model errors due to its statistical learning nature[22]. Furthermore, by extending the convergence analysis in[20] to the scenario of FL with downlink communication erros, we investigate the relationship between the bit error rate (BER) and the convergence rate of wireless FL, and determine the maximum tolerable BER that can maintain the same convergence rate as the case with error-free communication. Finally, we propose a practical approach to adjust the number of channel decoding iterations in each communication round to achieve the maximum tolerable BER, while reducing the energy consumption of mobile clients in wireless FL.

I-B Contributions

This paper investigates the impact of channel decoding on the energy efficiency of wireless FL. Our major contributions are summarized as follows:

  • â€¢

    We theoretically analyze the relationship between BER and the convergence rate of wireless FL. Specially, an upper bound of the average expected gradient norm of the global training loss with respect to BERs over communication rounds is derived by extending the analysis in [20], based on which, the maximum tolerable BER to achieve the same convergence rate as error-free FL is determined.

  • â€¢

    Based on the theoretical analysis, an adaptive low-density parity checking (LDPC) decoding mechanism is proposed, which controls the maximum number of decoding iterations to satisfy the BER requirement in every communication round and maintain the target convergence rate as error-free wireless FL, while reducing the energy consumption of channel decoders in wireless FL.

  • â€¢

    Experimental results on both IID and non-IID datasets show that the proposed adaptive scheme effectively reduces the energy consumption of channel decoders by 20% when compared with the traditional schemes which set a fixed maximum number of channel decoding iterations, while guaranteeing the same learning performance.

I-C Organization

The remainder of this paper is organized as follows. Section II introduces the system model and presents a comprehensive energy consumption analysis for mobile units. Section III develops an energy-efficient adaptive LDPC decoding scheme for wireless FL systems by exploiting the relationship between the convergence rate and the achieved BER of LDPC decoding. Experimental results are presented in Section IV. Finally, conclusions are drawn in Section V.

II System Model and Preliminaries

In this section, we first introduce the wireless FL system. An overview regarding the energy consumption of different components at a mobile unit (i.e., client) is then presented, which highlights the significant contribution of channel decoding to the total energy consumption of wireless FL. For ease of reference, we list the key notations in TableÂ I.

II-A Wireless FL

Fig.Â 1(a) depicts a wireless FL system, where model training of different clients is coordinated by a remote server. The FL problem can be formulated as follows [23, 24, 25]:

In this work, we focus on the downlink communication rather than the uplink since our objective is to design novel channel decoding schemes to save the energy consumption of mobile clients. II-B Energy Consumption Evaluation

There are two main energy-consuming operations for clients participating in wireless FL, namely model training and model communication. For the latter, it is believed that the energy is mostly consumed by the data transmission. In this section, we evaluate the energy consumption of different components, taking the training of AlexNet for image classification tasks as an example [26]. The analysis is based on actual measurements obtained from fabricated chips published in recent yearsÂ [27, 28, 29]. For fair comparisons, all data are collected for chips fabricated in the 65Â nm complementary metal-oxide semiconductor (CMOS) process.

In[27], a fabricated AI hardware accelerator was reported to achieve the energy efficiency of 13.7Â mJ/epoch for 8-bit quantized AlexNet. With five epochs of local training, the processing energy consumption in each communication round is 68.5Â mJ. In [28], a fifth-generation (5G) New Radio wireless transmitter and receiver were reported to achieve the energy efficiencies of 47.9Â pJ/b and 33.3Â pJ/b for transferring uncoded data, respectively, under a communication distance of around 200 meters. Therefore, the energy required to transmit and receive the 8-bit AlexNet with 60 million parameters in a single communication round is about 39Â mJ. Assuming a code rate of 1/2, the communication energy consumption for coded transmission of the AlexNet model parameters in each round is 78Â mJ. Besides, the LDPC decoder in [29] achieves the energy efficiency of 20.1Â pJ/b/iteration, which was measured with 10 decoding iterations on average. Accordingly, the energy consumption of the LDPC decoder for decoding the AlexNet model parameters is 96.5Â mJ. The detailed comparison is presented in Table II, which indicates that the energy consumption of LDPC decoding accounts for a large proportion of the overall energy consumption at clients in wireless FL.

II-C LDPC Decoding

In this work, we use LDPC codes as an example to illustrate how adaptive channel decoding can help reduce the energy consumption of wireless FL. In LDPC, the iterative decoding process continues until Qğ‘„Q decoding iterations, denoted as the maximum number of decoding iterations, are completedÂ [30]. Such iterative LDPC decoding processing leads to high energy consumption. To save the decoding energy, early termination techniques are usually adopted. Specifically, if the decoded codewords can fully pass the parity check, the decoding process will stop even if not all the Qğ‘„Q decoding iterations has been completed[31]. The early termination scheme can save decoding iterations without compromising the BER performance. The energy consumption of LDPC decoding depends on the target BER and thus the pre-defined maximum number of decoding iterations. As a result, to minimize the energy consumption, it is essential to determine the maximum tolerable BER by FL systems, considering its unique statistical learning nature.

III Energy-Efficient LDPC Decoding Design

In this section, we propose an energy-efficient LDPC decoding scheme to minimize the decoding energy consumption while guaranteeing the same convergence rate for wireless FL as the case with error-free communication. For that purpose, we explore the relationship between BER and convergence rate, and that between the maximum number of decoding iterations and BER. By connecting these two relationships, we demonstrate how to regulate the LDPC decoding scheme.

III-A Effect of BER on the Convergence Rate of Wireless FL

With error-free communication, the convergence rate of FL with non-convex loss functions is proved as ğ’ªâ€‹(1/T)ğ’ª1ğ‘‡\mathcal{O}(1/\sqrt{T}) [20], where Tğ‘‡T is the total number of SGD iterations. In this subsection, we investigate how BER affects the convergence rate of FL and determine the maximum admissible BER for maintaining the convergence rate of ğ’ªâ€‹(1/T)ğ’ª1ğ‘‡\mathcal{O}(1/\sqrt{T}).

Unlike FL with analog communication[32, 33, 34, 35, 36, 37, 38], quantifying the impact of BER on FL with digital communication is not straightforward. In particular, we need to consider different cases of bit errors and analyze the impact of different bit errors, e.g., most significant bits and least significant bits.

To conduct the theoretical analysis, we take the following assumptions that are widely adopted in the literature.

(Lğ¿L-SmoothnessÂ [13, 20]) The loss function fâ€‹(â‹…)ğ‘“â‹…f\left(\cdot\right) is Lğ¿L-smooth, i.e., âˆ€ğ°,ğ¯for-allğ°ğ¯\forall\mathbf{w},\mathbf{v}, we have â€–âˆ‡fâ€‹(ğ°)âˆ’âˆ‡fâ€‹(ğ¯)â€–â‰¤Lâ€‹â€–ğ°âˆ’ğ¯â€–normâˆ‡ğ‘“ğ°âˆ‡ğ‘“ğ¯ğ¿normğ°ğ¯||\nabla f(\mathbf{w})-\nabla f(\mathbf{v})||\leq L||\mathbf{w}-\mathbf{v}||.

Assumption 4.

(Independent Bit Errors [40]) Each bit in the bitstream of the decoded model parameters encounters error independently.

With the Nğ‘N-bit representation, each model parameter has 2Nâˆ’1superscript2ğ‘12^{N}-1 possible distorted patterns. However, our empirical results in Fig.Â 4 show that it is sufficient to focus on cases with at most one bit error of each model parameter. In particular, Fig.Â 4 compares the actual model error with the analytical model error expression in (7) assuming at most 1-bit error, which match closely with various BER. Therefore, we impose the following assumption to simplify our analysis.

Assumption 5.

(At Most 1-bit Error of each Model Parameter) There is at most 1-bit error in the Nğ‘N-bit representation of each model parameter.

Remark 1.

It is worthy noting that the first term on the RHS of (9) captures the distance between the initial and minimum global training loss. The second and third terms indicates how bit errors in each communication round affect learning convergence. The last two terms stem from non-IID data among clients and the random mini-batch sampling.

According to TheoremÂ 1, in order to guarantee the convergence rate of ğ’ªâ€‹(1/T)ğ’ª1ğ‘‡\mathcal{O}(1/\sqrt{T}), it is crucial to control the BER in each communication round such that the RHS of (10) reduces to zero at a rate of ğ’ªâ€‹(1/T)ğ’ª1ğ‘‡\mathcal{O}(1/\sqrt{T}). Since the explicit relationship between brsubscriptğ‘ğ‘Ÿb_{r} and rğ‘Ÿr is difficult to obtain, we propose a simple BER regulation method in CorollaryÂ 1. As such, wireless FL systems can achieve the same convergence rate as those with error-free communication.

Corollary 1.

If the BER in each communication round is regulated as

brâˆ1(r+1)2,r=0,â‹¯,Râˆ’1,formulae-sequenceproportional-tosubscriptğ‘ğ‘Ÿ1superscriptğ‘Ÿ12ğ‘Ÿ0â‹¯ğ‘…1\displaystyle b_{r}\propto\frac{1}{(r+1)^{2}},r=0,\cdots,R-1, (11)

the RHS of (10) diminishes to zero at a rate of ğ’ªâ€‹(1/T)ğ’ª1ğ‘‡\mathcal{O}(1/\sqrt{T}), i.e., wireless FL converges to a local optimal solution of the global training loss funcation at a rate of ğ’ªâ€‹(1/T)ğ’ª1ğ‘‡\mathcal{O}(1/\sqrt{T}).

we conclude the proof by letting Tâ†’âˆâ†’ğ‘‡T\rightarrow\infty for both sides of (13) and applying the Sandwich Theorem. âˆ

Corollary 1 indicates that gradually decreasing the BER at a rate of ğ’ªâ€‹(1/(r+1)2)ğ’ª1superscriptğ‘Ÿ12\mathcal{O}(1/(r+1)^{2}) can guarantee wireless FL converges at a rate of ğ’ªâ€‹(1/T)ğ’ª1ğ‘‡\mathcal{O}(1/\sqrt{T}). The proposed BER regulation rule achieves an improving communication quality with communication rounds. This is consistent with the solution developed in [36], which improves the communication quality by increasing the signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) with communication round.

III-B BER vs. Number of Iterations

The analysis in Section III-A indicates that the convergence rate of wireless FL with error-free communication can be achieved if the BER is properly controlled. In this subsection, we analyze the relationship between BER and the maximum number of LDPC decoding iterations, based on which, we develop an adaptive decoding scheme to maintain the same convergence rate.

It has been shown in [41] that for message-passing-based channel decoders to achieve a fraction of 1-Ïµitalic-Ïµ\epsilon of the channel capacity over a binary erasure channel, the relationship between the decoding complexity (denoted as Ï‡Dsubscriptğœ’ğ·\chi_{D}) and BER (denoted as bğ‘b) can be modeled as follows:

Ï‡D=ğ’ªâ€‹(logâ¡1b)+ğ’ªâ€‹(1Ïµâ€‹logâ¡1Ïµ).subscriptğœ’ğ·ğ’ª1ğ‘ğ’ª1italic-Ïµ1italic-Ïµ\chi_{D}=\mathcal{O}\left(\log\frac{1}{b}\right)+\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{1}{\epsilon}\log\frac{1}{\epsilon}\right). (14)

According to [42], the relationship between the decoding complexity and the maximum number of decoding iterations (Qğ‘„Q) can be modeled as follows:

Ï‡D=Qâ‹…Ï‡0,subscriptğœ’ğ·â‹…ğ‘„subscriptğœ’0\chi_{D}=Q\cdot\chi_{0}, (15)

where Ï‡0subscriptğœ’0\chi_{0} denotes the decoding complexity per iteration. By combining (14) and (15), it leads to the following relationship between the maximum number of decoding iterations and BER:

Q=1Ï‡0â€‹ğ’ªâ€‹(logâ¡1b)+1Ï‡0â€‹ğ’ªâ€‹(1Ïµâ€‹logâ¡1Ïµ).ğ‘„1subscriptğœ’0ğ’ª1ğ‘1subscriptğœ’0ğ’ª1italic-Ïµ1italic-ÏµQ=\frac{1}{\chi_{0}}\mathcal{O}\left(\log\frac{1}{b}\right)+\frac{1}{\chi_{0}}\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{1}{\epsilon}\log\frac{1}{\epsilon}\right). (16)

In the next subsection, we develop an adaptive scheme to control the maximum number of decoding iterations for clients in a wireless FL system based on Corollary 1 and (16).

III-C Decoding Iteration Control

In this subsection, we show how to adaptively control the maximum number of LDPC decoding iterations over communication rounds to achieve the desired BER.

In principle, by combining (11) and (16), we obtain the following relationship between the maximum number of LDPC decoding iterations and communication rounds:

Qr=1Ï‡0â€‹ğ’ªâ€‹(2â€‹logâ¡r)+1Ï‡0â€‹ğ’ªâ€‹(1Ïµâ€‹logâ¡1Ïµ),subscriptğ‘„ğ‘Ÿ1subscriptğœ’0ğ’ª2ğ‘Ÿ1subscriptğœ’0ğ’ª1italic-Ïµ1italic-ÏµQ_{r}=\frac{1}{\chi_{0}}\mathcal{O}\left(2\log\ r\right)+\frac{1}{\chi_{0}}\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{1}{\epsilon}\log\frac{1}{\epsilon}\right), (17)

which provides a guideline to select the maximum number of LDPC decoding iterations in the rğ‘Ÿr-th communication round. Specifically, Qrsubscriptğ‘„ğ‘ŸQ_{r} can be set as Î±â€‹logâ¡r+Î²ğ›¼ğ‘Ÿğ›½\alpha\log r+\beta, where Î±ğ›¼\alpha and Î²ğ›½\beta are constants. However, (17) cannot be directly utilized because Î±ğ›¼\alpha and Î²ğ›½\beta are code-specific and depend on the receive SNR as well as channel decoding algorithms. Thus, we propose a practical approach by the mapping relationship which captures the relationship between BER and the maximum number of decoding iterations at different levels of receive SNR. Entries in the mapping relationship can be obtained through empirical measurements specific to the LDPC code used in the wireless FL system. Fig.Â 5 shows the exampled simulation results for a rate 1/2 LDPC code with a block length of 1008 bits and binary phase shift keying (BPSK) modulation over an additional white Gaussian noise (AWGN) channel with SNR=1.5SNR1.5\text{SNR}=1.5 and 2.5 dB. Data in this figure can be stored in memoryÂ [43]. From the mapping relationship, we can get the corresponding maximum number of decoding iteration for a target BER for clients with different receive SNR.

The wireless FL procedures with adaptive LDPC decoding are summarized in AlgorithmÂ 1. The algorithm starts with an initial target BER, denoted as b0subscriptğ‘0b_{0}, which is set to a relatively high value, i.e., 10âˆ’1superscript10110^{-1} in our experiments. The target BER at the last communication round, denoted as bRâˆ’1subscriptğ‘ğ‘…1b_{R-1}, is set as a small value, i.e., 10âˆ’4superscript10410^{-4} in our experiments. The concrete expression of brsubscriptğ‘ğ‘Ÿb_{r} in our experiment is br=0.0999â€‹R2(R2âˆ’1)â€‹(r+1)2+10âˆ’4â€‹R2âˆ’0.1R2âˆ’1subscriptğ‘ğ‘Ÿ0.0999superscriptğ‘…2superscriptğ‘…21superscriptğ‘Ÿ12superscript104superscriptğ‘…20.1superscriptğ‘…21b_{r}=\frac{0.0999R^{2}}{(R^{2}-1)(r+1)^{2}}+\frac{10^{-4}R^{2}-0.1}{R^{2}-1}. For each communication round, the BER is scaled according to (11), and the corresponding maximum number of LDPC decoding iterations in that round is obtained from the mapping relationship.

Remark 2.

Note that the number of entries in the mapping relationship depends on the possible discrete BER and SNR values. Since this number is not large, the memory overhead for storing the mapping relationship is expected to be small. Additionally, reading data from the memory takes constant time and does not introduce additional LDPC decoding latency.

IV Experimental Results

In this section, we validate the effectiveness of the proposed adaptive LDPC decoding algorithm via numerical experiments. First, we introduce the experimental settings. Then, the performance of the proposed algorithm, including test accuracy and energy consumption, is compared with a baseline with a fixed number of LDPC decoding iterations.

IV-A Experimental Settings

System Setups: We consider an FL system with 10 clients. All clients are assumed to be selected in every communication round and they communicate with the server using rate 1/2 min-sum LDPC code with a code length of 1008 bits[44]. Besides, binary phase shift keying (BPSK) is adopted as the modulation scheme. In each communication round, the number of local SGD steps is set as 5 with the learning rate and batch size as 0.01 and 64, respectively. The receive SNR of all the wireless channels is assumed to be 2.5 dB.

Datasets: We conduct experiments on three dataset, including MNIST[45], Fashion-MNIST[46], and CIFAR-10[47]. The training datasets are distributed among clients in an IID manner. We further consider one experiment where the Fashion-MNIST data are non-IID among clients. In particular, each client was assigned with two categories of training data, similar to the setup in [24]. The test datasets are used for validation at the server.

DNN Models: For the MNIST dataset, the LeNet-300-100 model[48] is employed, which is a fully connected neural network consisting of two hidden layers and one softmax layer, with approximately 0.27 million parameters. For the Fashion-MNIST dataset, a vanilla CNN [3] with two 5Ã—5 convolution layers, one fully connected layer, and one softmax layer is employed, comprising around 0.58 million parameters. For the CIFAR-10 dataset, a 7-layer CNN model with four 3Ã—3 convolution layers, two fully connected layers, and one softmax layer is employed, which contains approximately 9.07 million parameters.

IV-B Learning Performance of Conventional Schemes

In this subsection, experimental results for the baseline scheme are presented. As shown in Fig.Â 6, it leads to approximately constant BERs over the training process.

Next, we investigate the impact of a constant BER on the performance of wireless FL. Fig.Â 7 summarizes the test accuracy with different maximum numbers of decoding iterations. It can be observed that for all the four FL tasks, when the BER is higher than 10âˆ’3superscript10310^{-3}, the learning performance was significantly impaired. Lowering the BER to 10âˆ’4superscript10410^{-4} leads to improved accuracy and faster convergence towards wireless FL with error-free communication. However, further decreasing the BER to 10âˆ’5superscript10510^{-5} does not yield any significant improvement in test accuracy.

IV-C Learning Performance of the Proposed Scheme

In this subsection, the proposed adaptive LDPC decoding scheme is compared to the baseline scheme. Specifically, the learning process of the proposed scheme is assigned with an initial BER of 10âˆ’1superscript10110^{-1} and a final BER value of 10âˆ’4superscript10410^{-4}. The desired BER at every communication round is calculated via (11) and the maximum number of LDPC decoding iterations is determined according to the mapping with BER as stated in SectionÂ III. In the experiments, the initial and final maximum numbers of LDPC decoding iterations are thus set to 6 and 24, respectively. For the baseline scheme, a maximum of 24 LDPC decoding iterations are used in each communication round, which corresponds to a BER of 10âˆ’4superscript10410^{-4}.

Fig.Â 8(a) shows an example on the Fashion-MNIST (IID) datasets to illustrate the actual number of decoding iterations for each frame of data bits. It can observed that only a few frames exhaust all the decoding iterations which is set to a large value of 52. Note that the decoding energy consumption is proportional to the actual number of decoding iterations used for the FL tasks. From the distribution on the actual number of decoding iterations shown in Fig.Â 8(b), it is observed that 18 decoding iterations are sufficient for most cases, implying the significant reduction of energy consumption.

Fig.Â 9 summarizes the experimental results for LeNet-300-100 on the MNIST (IID) dataset. Specifically, Fig.Â 9(a) shows how the maximum number of LDPC decoding iterations varies with communication rounds in the proposed scheme. While the baseline scheme with a fixed number of maximum decoding iterations results in a constant BER, the proposed scheme achieves the desired BER by adopting a linearly increasing maximum number of decoding iterations. Fig.Â 9(b) shows the test accuracy achieved by different schemes. It is observed that setting the maximum number of decoding iterations to 6 (which corresponds to a BER of âˆ¼10âˆ’1similar-toabsentsuperscript101\sim 10^{-1}) severely affects the learning accuracy. Similarly, when the maximum number of decoding iterations is set to 12 (which corresponds to a BER of âˆ¼10âˆ’2similar-toabsentsuperscript102\sim 10^{-2}), the training process still fails to converge. By setting the maximum number of decoding iterations as 18 (which corresponds to a BER of âˆ¼10âˆ’3similar-toabsentsuperscript103\sim 10^{-3}), the training process converges, but with a noticeable loss in test accuracy compared to the case when the maximum number of decoding iterations is 24 (which corresponds to a BER of âˆ¼10âˆ’4similar-toabsentsuperscript104\sim 10^{-4}). However, further increasing the maximum number of decoding iterations to 52 does not lead to much accuracy improvement.

The proposed scheme, which linearly increases the maximum number of decoding iterations from 6 to 24, achieves the same test accuracy as those with fixed 24 or 52 decoding iterations. Fig.Â 9(c) illustrates how the average number of decoding iterations over all DNN parameters varies during the training process. The proposed scheme can reduce the average number of decoding iterations and thus the overall energy consumption. Fig.Â 9(d) depicts the BER of the proposed scheme over communication rounds, which scales as ğ’ªâ€‹(1/(r+1)2)ğ’ª1superscriptğ‘Ÿ12\mathcal{O}(1/(r+1)^{2}) from 10âˆ’1superscript10110^{-1} to 10âˆ’4superscript10410^{-4}. Fig.Â 9(e) shows the final test accuracy of different schemes at the 50-th communication round. It can be observed that the proposed scheme achieves the same accuracy as the baseline schemes that always maintain a very low BER of 10âˆ’4superscript10410^{-4} and 10âˆ’5superscript10510^{-5} throughout the training process. Fig.Â 9(f) illustrates the decoding energy consumption on clients under different schemes. It is obtained by multiplying the total number of LDPC decoding iterations with the LDPC decoding energy efficiency reported in [29]. Compared to the baseline scheme with a maximum of 24 decoding iterations, the proposed scheme reduces the overall decoding energy consumption by 19.4%.

Figs.Â 10, 11, and 12 present the experimental results for Fashion-MNIST (IID), CIFAR-10 (IID), and Fashion-MNIST (non-IID) datasets, respectively. The results are similar to those on the MNIST (IID) dataset in Fig.Â 9, showing that adapting the maximum number of LDPC decoding iterations can achieve similar or even slightly better accuracy compared to the baseline scheme. This observation was also reported in [49, 50, 51], which suggests that adding annealed noise to the DNN model could enhance its generalization ability. Moreover, the proposed scheme reduces the LDPC decoding energy consumption on the Fashion-MNIST (IID), CIFAR-10 (IID), and Fashion-MNIST (non-IID) datasets by 18.3%, 20.1%, and 18.0%, respectively. TableÂ III provides a summary of the experimental data.

V Conclusion

In this paper, we considered the energy consumption issue in wireless federated learning (FL) over digital communication networks. Our study recognized that channel decoding contributes to a large portion of the energy consumption at mobile clients in wireless FL systems. To achieve energy-efficient wireless FL, we first show that by properly controlling the bit error rate (BER) over different communication rounds, wireless FL can achieve the same convergence rate as FL with error-free communication. Based on this analysis, we proposed an energy-efficient LDPC decoding scheme to regulate the maximum number of decoding iterations over communication rounds. Experimental results demonstrated that the proposed method can reduce approximately 20% of the total energy consumed by LDPC decoding, while maintaining the same or even a slightly higher learning accuracy compared to the scheme without adaptive decoding iteration control.
